Based on the search results, I can provide you with a comprehensive overview of the academic analysis and literary criticism of Animal Farm's symbolism and allegory:

## Overview of Animal Farm as Political Allegory

Animal Farm is a satirical allegorical novella by George Orwell that reflects events leading up to the Russian Revolution of 1917 and then on into the Stalinist era of the Soviet Union. The novel allegorizes the Russian Revolution of 1917, when the tsarist autocracy was pushed out and the Bolsheviks came into power, and the revolution's incremental betrayal of its supporters under dictator Joseph Stalin.

## Key Character Symbolism

### The Pigs as Soviet Leaders
Old Major represents Karl Marx, while Snowball is the allusion of Leon Trotsky, the intellectual, who was chased out of the farm. Napoleon is an allegory of Joseph Stalin, while Snowball parallels Leon Trotsky, who is exiled from the farm and subsequently becomes an image of evil. Squealer serves as Napoleon's second-in-command and minister of propaganda, is a collective portrait of the Soviet nomenklatura and journalists.

### Other Animals and Their Symbolic Meanings
Boxer, in many ways, is an example of the perfect proletarian (worker). He never complains; he is extremely loyal; and he literally works himself to death. The common workers, symbolized by Clover the horse and Muriel the goat, end up working without seeing the benefits of their work.

## Major Symbols and Their Interpretations

### The Windmill
The divide between Stalin and Trotsky (Napoleon and Snowball) is represented by the argument over the windmill. The windmill, a project which is supposed to bring wealth and prosperity to the farm, becomes a symbol of the manipulation and exploitation of the public. Napoleon then takes credit for Snowball's plan to build a windmill – symbolic of Lenin's modernization plans.

### The Barn and Commandments
The barn symbolizes the seat of power in Animal Farm. It begins as a place where all animals are equal, but the pigs slowly change the commandments on the wall and establish power for themselves. Squealer is employed to alter the commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history to exercise control of the people's beliefs.

### The Farm Itself
Manor farm, later Animal Farm after the revolution, stands for the Soviet Union. Animal Farm, the barn, the windmill, and the gun are symbols of different gadgets that the animals place value to show that they have brought a revolution.

## Themes and Literary Analysis

### Totalitarianism and Corruption
Cast in the form of an allegory, this beast fable is a harsh satire that condemns totalitarianism. In particular, Orwell targets the Soviet Union's brand of communism as nothing more than the ideology of a police state. In the context of its allegory, Orwell's novella suggests that totalitarianism and hypocrisy are natural outcomes of conspiratorial political movements.

### Language and Propaganda
The most famous line in the book is "All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others", which tells us typical of Orwell's belief that those in power usually manipulate language to their own benefit. Orwell was committed to communicating straightforwardly, given the way that he felt words were commonly used in politics to deceive and confuse.

### The Betrayal of Revolutionary Ideals
Rather than eliminating the capitalist class system it was intended to overthrow, the revolution merely replaced it with another hierarchy. The narrative cultivates considerable sympathy for the animal's thinly allegorized Marxian cause in the early stages of the revolution. However, the thrust of Orwell's allegorical critique lies in the hasty corruption of this cause in the revolution's aftermath.

## Scholarly Reception and Criticism

John Molyneux summed up Animal Farm as "probably the most popular and influential piece of literary propaganda produced in English, perhaps in any language, this century". Scholars such as Paul Kirschner have tried to reclaim the text as not only a political but also a literary work, reminding readers of Orwell's own declared intention "to fuse political purpose and artistic purpose into one whole".

## Contemporary Relevance

Animal Farm deserves reassessment as a complex work of fiction rather than a simple history lesson on the U.S.S.R. While this article explains how Animal Farm allegorizes Soviet history, it also points to richer themes and symbolism that often escape attention for what they can tell us about revolutionary politics. Orwell's intention in using an allegory was to highlight not just the wrong doings during Russian Revolution but the perils of allowing leaders to become too powerful.

The academic consensus views Animal Farm as a masterful political allegory that uses animal characters and farm symbolism to critique totalitarian regimes, particularly Stalin's Soviet Union, while also offering universal warnings about the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of language for political control.
